pullRequest.body:
A general framework for proving analytic continuation & functional equations via Mellin transforms.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

(Note to reviewers: this is a generalisation of the existing argument used in the Riemann zeta function code; but I have not refactored the existing code using this just yet, since I will shortly be PR'ing more general results for Hurwitz and Dirichlet L-series, and Riemann zeta will eventually just be a special case of these.)

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

I agree!
I think there is not much more to do with this PR and it seems ready to go.

This looks like a great work, thanks! I will try to have a closer look later.
This looks like a great work, thanks! I will try to have a closer look later.
LGTM!
Do you want to say what $f_0$ and $g_0$ are here? I agree it is clear from the code, but in this (very nice!) introduction they might also appear and I cannot find them.

```suggestion
/-- As `x â†’ âˆž`, `F x` decays faster than any power of `x`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma Differentiable_Î› : Differentiable â„‚ P.Î› := fun s â†¦
```
I don't think that's the convention, is it? `Differentiable` is `Type`-valued, but `differentiable_Î›` is term-valued (it constructs a term of type `Differentiable xxx`) so it is lowercased.
Yep, good point. Sorry for the noise.
Can you add some intermediate comments that explain the structure of the proof?

Then why not defined a parametrised version (say, `f_mod'`) where `1` is a variable, in case we later need to split this at another point? You can then use an `abbreviation` to set this to `1` in the rest of your file. Probably I would also stick to the whole "modified" or "modif" to avoid confusion with "mod" for modular/modulo.

There's two separate issues here â€“ choosing where to split the integral, and choosing what value to assign for `f_mod` at the split point. The comment is about the latter, but I think you are perhaps misreading it as the former (which is a much more mathematically interesting issue!).


For the former: I did consider adding an extra parameter `N` in the `FEPair` class, allowing a functional equation relating `t` and `N / t`, and splitting the integral at `sqrt N`; but it all became quite messy. I think it'll be easier just to scale the variables when applying this to higher-level modular forms.

I think the latter (boring) issue, assigning the value at the endpoint, is not likely to be of interest outside the context of this particular proof.

I indeed misread it for the former and was thinking about the more general functional equation. But then I would maintain the idea that parametrizing over the split point could make sense, without changing the whole set-up here, with an `abbrev`. It might just be an inspiration for further work.

As for choosing the value I agree that it is not worth making any fuzz about it.

If we allow a general "level" parameter `0 < N`, and let the functional equation hypothesis be `f (N / t) = (stuff) * g x`, then what should the "stuff" be? If we have
````
f (N / x) = Îµ * x ^ k * g x
````
then we lose the symmetry (`P.symm.Îµ = P.Îµâ»Â¹`) which holds with the current setup. If we make it
````
f (N / x) = Îµ * (x / sqrt(N)) ^ k * g x
````
then the symmetry is restored, but the proofs of the intermediate results become yet more complicated.

How about the following? If we find in future that the corresponding results for non-trivial "level" parameters are useful, we can add (in a future PR) classes `WeakFEPairWithLevel` and `StrongFEPairWithLevel`. Then we can prove some simple lemma to the effect that if `f, g` are a `WeakFEPairWithLevel` N, then `f (Â· / sqrt N), g (Â· / sqrt N)` are a `WeakFEPair` of level 1, and level N generalisations of all the results on FE-pairs will follow easily.

Sure, that makes sense. I was suggesting a very low-level modifications, namely simply adding the `modif_withLevel` modified version and immediately after setting an abbreviation for `mod_f` (or modif_f) being the `modif_withLevel 1`. But I agree that without adding any further lemma this is not so useful, so your remark is perfectly fine: you could add a `ToDo` line at the beginning with the above remark.
I've added a TODO comment.
Great, IMHO this PR is ready to go.

```suggestion
/-- A modified strong FE-pair derived from a string FE-pair `(f, g)` by subtracting a suitable correction term. -/
```
String theory? :smile:
Sorry, typing with iPad ...
Are the functions really defined only on the positive reals? It doesn't seem so.
Of course, what I really mean is that only their values on the positive reals will matter. Happy to rephrase it

```suggestion
  rw [(div_div_cancel' (one_ne_zero' â„) â–¸ P.h_feq (1 / x) (one_div_pos.mpr hx) :), â† mul_smul]
  convert (one_smul â„‚ (P.g (1 / x))).symm using 2
  rw [one_div, inv_rpow hx.le, ofReal_inv]
  field_simp [P.hÎµ, ofReal_ne_zero.mpr (rpow_pos_of_pos hx _).ne']
```
Do as you prefer.
Do you think is it worth to have this as a separate lemma?
I've added a couple of `rfl` lemmas and used them to get rid of the `change` calls.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion P.symm.Î›â‚€ s = P.symm.Î› s + (1 / s) â€¢ P.gâ‚€ + (P.Îµâ»Â¹ / (P.k - s)) â€¢ P.fâ‚€ := by ```

```suggestion
### Main definitions and results
```
Can you explain what `F` is in the docstring?
Would it simplify things later (if only slightly) if one uses `r` in place of `-r`?

```suggestion
/-- As `x â†’ âˆž`, `f x` decays faster than any power of `x`. -/
```
At least, this is what the statement says...

```suggestion
/-- As `x â†’ 0`, `f x` decays faster than any power of `x`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma hasMellin (s : â„‚) : HasMellin P.f s (P.Î› s) :=
```

```suggestion
lemma Î›_eq : P.Î› = mellin P.f := rfl
```
(very slightly more efficient)

```suggestion
lemma symm_Î›_eq : P.symm.Î› = mellin P.g := rfl
```

```suggestion
  rw [â† sub_eq_add_neg, sub_right_comm, sub_self, zero_sub, step1] at step2
```

```suggestion
there is no "good" choice of value at `1`. -/
```
This looks like something `fun_prop` should be able to solve automatically at some point. Unfortunately, right now, it does not yet work...

```suggestion
  Â· simp [f_modif, g_modif]
```
(a bit slower, though).

Why not call it simply `strongFEPair`? The name looks like the strong FE-pair is somehow modified, but what the function does is to associate a strong pair to a weak one (and I assume there is only one reasonable way of doing that).

I wanted to make it clear in the name that the resulting strong FE pair does *not* have the same underlying functions as the weak FE pair does â€“Â it's different underlying data, not the same data repackaged. There is definitely a lot of choice in how one constructs a strong FE pair from a weak one: strong FE-pairs are a codimension 2 subspace in the space of weak FE-pairs, and we are choosing a specific complementary subspace.

OK; I can see that one could, e.g., choose more general splitting points `t` and `1/t` instead of `1` and `1` in the definition of the modified functions. Still, I don't quite like the name and would prefer that `modif` is removed. I think the "making clear that" is better done in the docstring.

Do you have an alternative suggestion for a naming scheme? If `WeakFEPair.modifStrongFEPair` becoms `WeakFEPair.strongFEPair`, then what should the lemmas needed in building this object, e.g. `WeakFEPair.hf_modif_int`, be called?

I think it's OK to leave the other names as they are, as they indeed talk about modified versions of the data. I would consider them implementation details of the projection to strong pairs, which is the main goal here. The difference is what `modif` appears to refer to.

Maybe `WeakFEPair.toStrongFEPair` captures a bit better what this is intended to do?
I have changed it to `WeakFEPair.toStrongFEPair`, while leaving the preliminary lemmas unchanged, as suggested.

```suggestion
  Â· simp [add_comm, sub_eq_add_neg]
```
would do it (or `simp; abel`, but this would run afoul of the non-terminal `simp` linter, I guess...).
Not sure it's really better, though.

```suggestion
  refine ((P.differentiable_Î›â‚€ s).sub ?_).sub ?_
```
`abel` is not necessary when giving `add_comm` and `sub_eq_add_neg` to `simp`.

```suggestion
    (fun x â†¦ P.f x - (P.Îµ * â†‘(x ^ (-P.k))) â€¢ P.gâ‚€) =O[ð“[>] 0] (Â· ^ r) := by
  have := (P.hg_top (-(r + P.k))).comp_tendsto tendsto_inv_zero_atTop
```
plus some corrections in the proof, which I hope the suggestions below will do.

```suggestion
  simp_rw [Function.comp_apply, â† one_div, P.h_feq' _ hx] at hC'
```

```suggestion
  Â· simp_rw [norm_mul, norm_real, one_div, inv_rpow hx.le, norm_inv,
      norm_of_nonneg (rpow_pos_of_pos hx _).le, rpow_neg hx.le, rpow_add hx]
```

```suggestion
lemma hf_top' (r : â„) : P.f =O[atTop] (Â· ^ r) := by
```

```suggestion
lemma hf_zero' (r : â„) : P.f =O[ð“[>] 0] (Â· ^ r) := by
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨mellinConvergent_of_isBigO_rpow P.hf_int (P.hf_top' (-t)) ht (P.hf_zero' (-u)) hu, rflâŸ©
```
Since, AFAIK, mathlib has not yet decided about `lemma` vs `theorem` you can perhaps rename the main ones to `theorem` to help the reader understand the one you are referring to.
I have rebadged as `theorems` all the results that are specifically called out in the file-level header.
